author: maxvoltage.
content:
<@!779882055910948895> Honestly, there are both detractors and supporters of 1559 that have no idea how 1559 works and what its real intentions are.  The supporters constantly note the lowering of fees and deflation, and miners stating the devs are taking their transaction fees.  Both have nothing to do with what the intention of 1559 is.

With that said, those that started the 51 hour consolidation of hashrate know exactly why they proposed it.  It has been stated multiple times that there is no increased security threat due to 1559.  Scenarios were presented by <@!318272156305981440> showing that there were scenarios where there would be an increased threat with a specific proposal to raise the BR by 1 in order to decrease the possibility in the sudden shift of hashrate away from Ethereum.

Lastly, there has been at least one person and I believe more than one from ACD call participants that didn't believe a consolidation of hashrate could occur.  This is a real threat when 1559 goes into effect.  Many miners will move to profit switching miners (NiceHash, for example) which are also rental hashrates as Ehtereum may not be the dominant currency for mining profitability.

author: maxvoltage.
content: The mining community has heard the message loud and clear.  Decision makers don't believe the mining community can organize and don't believe a consolidation of hashrate can be coordinated.  They may be right, but the mining community is taking up the dare and doing it in a way that is nondestructive.  Consolidating at a pool such as Ehtermine, a well respected pool, will not cause a 51% attack.  It will only show that it is possible.

author: stakewars
content: <@604977744044097546> I agree with your first paragraph for sure. 1559 is not to take away income from miners and it is not to lower the fees. It is to make the fees more predicable (which could be argued as a way to lower them a bit if various services did not always need to ‘one up’ one another needlessly to make a transaction pull through. It’s as people say a better UX). I am more so concerned with miners thinking neither the dev community or the users matter. It comes off as pretentious and honestly needlessly aggressive. We’re all equally a piece of the pie. None of it would work with only 2/3 in the mix. I think we can all agree on that. The narrative really needs to change.

author: stakewars
content: Somehow 1559 was twisted as this evil plan to ruin the miner’s income.

author: stakewars
content: That’s simply not true. Everything needs to be taken into account. That includes the users and the devs.

author: maxvoltage.
content: <@!779882055910948895> I agree, but every attempt from the mining community to come to some agreement has been met with overwhelming opposition and arrogance that there isn't a security risk with this implementation of 1559.

author: stakewars
content: The way I think this should be looked at is such: fees are more predictable and make the ‘one up’ in fees less crazy which contributes to a better experience. As such people will keep using it and miners (despite the slight decrease to possible income) will have a robust healthy network to support. If this does not happen, then users leave and then it really makes no difference how secure the network is if no one wants to be on it

author: maxvoltage.
content: The real question that needs to be answered is "how much is enough to pay for security or, vice versa, how much is too much to pay for security?"  That is the real question that miners and the rest of the community can't come to agreement on.  It changes the equation of miners show that consolidation of hashrate is possible.
